reporting-org.narrative: Ministry for Foreign Affairs of Finland

title.narrative: ARMENIA/FLC The Fourth Working Meeting of Armenian Azeri and Georgian Historians and Civic Activists

description.narrative: Project's goal is further development of cooperation between historians and civic activists from Armenia Azerbaijan and Georgia as a follow-up for the Third Working Meeting Project. Summary of the project: 1) It is planned to organize a two-day conferenc e in Tbilisi (Georgia) with participation of the project staff academicians and experts-analysts from Armenia Azerbaijan and Georgia. The project staff will make presentations on the media coverage of the previous projects in their countries and will discu ss the next steps of the project. 2) Publication of 'Peace Scenario for the South Caucasus by 2025' by well-known experts-analysts on South Caucasus which will include several elements including analysis and policy recommendations. Each paper will be 10 pa ges and wil be published in 500 copies. The Papers will also be available online. The papers will consist of: a credible peace scenario for the South Caucasus by 2025 some concrete domestic measures/initiatives that would contribute to promote regional coo peration and integration in such areas as economy trade energy culture transports and/or environment and recommendations. 3) Digital conference of the project partners Armenia-Azerbaijan-Georgia. 4) Presentation of the publication 'Peace Scenario for the S outh Caucasus by 2025' in Baku (Azerbaijan) Yerevan (Armenia) and Tbilisi (Georgia). 5) Project coordinators' two-day meeting where the participants will discuss the project progress and will prepare follow-up program. The overall objective of the project is to provide society with the skills required to become tolerant citizens who are empowered to defend and promote democratic values in the South Caucasus. Project will play significant role in changing stereotype thinking of ordinary people in these count ries and building of trustful relations. In the long-term new methodologies and materials are introduced in the history classrooms of Armenia Azerbaijan and Georgia thus enabling students to develop their critical thinking skills and tolerance and contribu ting to reconciling deeply divided nations for a conflict-free future.
